dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2018, the UN reported that the number of people facing hunger is actually growing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty eighteen, the U N reported that the number of people facing hunger is actually growing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last years United Nations report on progress toward achieving the SDGs showed that the number of people facing hunger is actually growing, as is the number of malaria cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and malaria cases are on the rise too, which is just… really disheartening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and malaria cases are on the rise too, which is just... really disheartening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last years United Nations report on progress toward achieving the SDGs showed that the number of people facing hunger is actually growing, as is the number of malaria cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's hitting the poorest communities hardest. Like in Nigeria, access to basic health interventions is five times higher for the wealthiest compared to the lowest quintile.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's hitting the poorest communities hardest. Like in Nigeria, access to basic health interventions is five times higher for the wealthiest compared to the lowest quintile.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Nigeria, access to basic reproductive, maternal, newborn, and child health interventions remains five times higher for those in the top wealth quintile than those in the lowest (68%, compared to 13%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a massive gap. I mean, 68% versus 13%—that's not just a disparity, that's a crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a massive gap. I mean, sixty eight percent versus thirteen percent-that's not just a disparity, that's a crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Nigeria, access to basic reproductive, maternal, newborn, and child health interventions remains five times higher for those in the top wealth quintile than those in the lowest (68%, compared to 13%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Even in the U.S., there are huge inequities. In Baltimore, life expectancy differs by 18 years between neighborhoods just miles apart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even in the U.S., there are huge inequities. In Baltimore, life expectancy differs by eighteen years between neighborhoods just miles apart.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the United States, residents of Baltimores largely white and wealthy Roland Park neighborhood can expect to live 16 years longer than residents of the largely black, impoverished Greenmount East neighborhood, located just a few miles away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It really shows how deep these structural issues go. The SDGs promised no one would be left behind, but we're clearly not on track.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really shows how deep these structural issues go. The SDGs promised no one would be left behind, but we're clearly not on track.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is no way to fulfill the pledge contained in the SDG framework, called the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, that no one will be left behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that's where this health equity programs of action framework comes in—proposed by the O'Neill Institute.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that's where this health equity programs of action framework comes in-proposed by the O'Neill Institute.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The health equity programs of actionframework, proposed by the ONeill Institute for National and Global Health Law at the Georgetown University Law Center, aims to facilitate the development of just such a response.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, the one grounded in human rights obligations. It's got those seven principles, like enabling participation from marginalized groups.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, the one grounded in human rights obligations. It's got those seven principles, like enabling participation from marginalized groups.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Grounded in countries human rights obligations, the programs of action could be implemented through national health plans or through national development, SDG, or social inclusion strategies. They would adhere to seven principles: Enable empowering participation and inclusive leadership.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They want people from disadvantaged populations to be decision-makers, not just recipients of aid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They want people from disadvantaged populations to be decision-makers, not just recipients of aid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: People from disadvantaged and marginalized populations would be decision-makers, helping to lead all relevant structures and processes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just about healthcare systems—it's about all the social, economic, even political determinants of health.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just about healthcare systems-it's about all the social, economic, even political determinants of health.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The full range of social, cultural, environmental, economic, and political determinants of health must be considered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: They emphasize measurable targets and timelines too. You can't just have vague goals; you need specific actions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They emphasize measurable targets and timelines too. You can't just have vague goals; you need specific actions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Actions, targets, and timelines. Actions must be specific, and linked to measurable, time-bound targets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Accountability is huge as well—independent monitoring, capacity building… it has to be built into the system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Accountability is huge as well-independent monitoring, capacity building... it has to be built into the system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Actions and targets must be incorporated into sectoral strategies and encompass thorough monitoring and evaluation (including by independent entities), capacity building, and structures that embed accountability at all levels of the health system and other relevant systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But none of it works without sustained political commitment. Leaders have to actually care and fund this long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But none of it works without sustained political commitment. Leaders have to actually care and fund this long-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sustained high-level political commitment. Programs of action can be implemented only if political leaders have the will to work consistently and systematically over a prolonged period, allocating the relevant resources as needed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And we've got less than 12 years to achieve the SDGs. The clock is ticking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And we've got less than twelve years to achieve the SDGs. The clock is ticking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We have less than 12 years to achieve the SDGs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So adopting frameworks like this isn't optional—it's urgent. The UN and WHO should really push for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So adopting frameworks like this isn't optional-it's urgent. The U N and W H O should really push for it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The UN and the World Health Organization whose principles are consistent with those of the health equity programs of action should encourage governments to adopt this framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Health inequities aren't natural; they're created. Which means we can fix them, if there's the will.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Health inequities aren't natural; they're created. Which means we can fix them, if there's the will.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Health inequities are not inevitable. They are the product of injustices that people have created.
